lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` org.org.trashbot.disk, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: platform
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: platform
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: platform
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: platform
* The ByeCommand class represents a command that terminates the application.
* It implements the {@link Command} interface and provides the behavior for
* Executes the command, which terminates the program.
* This method calls {@link System#exit(int)} with a status code of 0,
* indicating a normal termination of the application.
* @param tasks the current list of tasks (not used in this command)
* @param storage the data persistence object (not used in this command)
* @return String containing the command's output message
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) {
* Provides abstract method "execute" to the implementing classes
* Execute the command and return a String containing the command's output
* @param tasks   list of tasks to operate on
* @return String containing the command's output message
* @throws DukeException if a custom error occurs during execution
* @throws IOException   if an I/O error occurs during file operation
String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) throws DukeException, IOException;
* Handles the creation and management of deadline-based tasks in the task management system.
* This command implementation processes user input to create new deadline tasks with specific
* due dates and adds them to the task list.

*

The command expects input in the format: "deadline <task> /by <due>"
* where <task> is the task description and <due> is the deadline date/time.
* DeadlineCommand cmd = new DeadlineCommand("submit report /by next Monday");
* Constructs a new DeadlineCommand with the specified input string.
* @param input The raw input string containing both the task description and deadline
* Executes the deadline command by creating a new deadline task and adding it to the task list.
* The method also persists the updated task list to storage.

*

The method parses the input string to create a new {@link Deadline} task. The input
* must contain the "/by" delimiter to separate the task description from the deadline.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks to which the new deadline task will be added
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism used to save the updated task list
* @return String containing the command's output message
* @throws InvalidFormatException if the input string does not contain the "/by" delimiter
*                                or is not in the correct format
* @throws IOException            if there is an error saving the task list to storage
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) throws InvalidFormatException, IOException {
throw new InvalidFormatException("Please use the format: deadline <task> /by <due>");
return String.format(" Got it. I've added this task:\n  %s\n Now you have %d tasks in the list.",
* Handles the deletion of tasks from the task management system.
* This command implementation removes a task at the specified index
* from the task list and updates the storage.

*

The command operates based on a task ID (index) which must be
* within the valid range of existing tasks (0 to size-1).
* DeleteCommand cmd = new DeleteCommand(2); // Delete the third task
* The index of the task to be deleted (0-based)
* Constructs a new DeleteCommand for the specified task ID.
* @param taskId The index of the task to be deleted (0-based index)
* Executes the delete command by removing the specified task from the task list
* and updating the storage. The method validates that the task ID is within
* the valid range before performing the deletion.

*

After successful deletion, the updated task list is persisted to storage
* and a confirmation message is displayed to the user.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks from which a task will be deleted
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism used to save the updated task list
* @return String containing the command's output message
* @throws InvalidFormatException if the task ID is out of range (less than 0 or
*                                greater than or equal to the size of the task list)
* @throws IOException            if there is an error saving the task list to storage
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) throws InvalidFormatException, IOException {
throw new InvalidFormatException("Task number must be between 1 and " + tasks.size());
return String.format(" Got it. I've removed this task: \n %s\n Now you have %d tasks in the list.",
* Handles the creation of event tasks.
* This command implementation processes user input to create new event tasks with specific
* starting and ending date/time, and add them to the task list.

*

The command expects input in the format: "event <task> /from <start> /to <end>"
* where <task> is the task description, <start> is the start date/time, and <end>
* Constructs a new EventCommand with the specified input string.
* @param input The raw input string containing both the task description and event
*              information in the format "task /from date/time /to date/time"
* Executes the event command by creating a new event task and adding it to the task list.
* The method also persists the updated task list to storage.

*

The method parses the input string to create a new {@link Event} task. The input
* must contain the "/from" and "/to" delimiter to separate the task description from the event.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks to which the new event task will be added
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism used to save the updated task list
* @return String containing the command's output message
* @throws InvalidFormatException if the input string does not contain the "/from" and "/to" delimiter
*                                or is not in the correct format
* @throws IOException            if there is an error saving the task list to storage
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) throws InvalidFormatException, IOException {
throw new InvalidFormatException("Please use the format: event /from <start> /to <end>");
return String.format(" Got it. I've added this task:\n  %s\n Now you have %d tasks in the list.",
* Handles searching for tasks containing specific keywords in the task management system.
* This command implementation filters tasks based on whether their descriptions contain

*

The command expects input in the format: "find <keyword>"
* where <keyword> is the search term to match against task descriptions.
* Constructs a new FindCommand with the specified search term.
* @param term The raw input string containing both the command and search term
* Executes the find command by searching through all tasks and displaying those
* whose descriptions contain the search term (case-insensitive match).

*

The method filters the task list and displays matching tasks with their
* indices. If no matching tasks are found, an appropriate message is shown.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks to search through
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism (unused in this implementation)
* @return String containing the command's output message
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) {
StringBuilder output = new StringBuilder(" Here are the matching tasks in the list:\n");
* Displays all tasks currently stored in the task management system.
* This command implementation provides a formatted view of all tasks
* in the task list, with each task numbered sequentially.

*

The output is formatted with decorative borders and includes:
* - Empty list notification if no tasks exist
* Here are the tasks in your list:
* Executes the list command by displaying all tasks in the task list.
* The method formats the output with sequential numbering and decorative borders.
* If the task list is empty, a special message is displayed instead.

*

The storage parameter is not used in this implementation as the command
* only reads and displays the current state of the task list without modification.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks to be displayed
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism (unused in this implementation)
* @return String containing the command's output message
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) {
StringBuilder output = new StringBuilder(" Here are the tasks in your list:\n");
* Handles marking tasks as done or not done in the task management system.
* This command implementation allows toggling the completion status of a
* specific task identified by its index in the task list.

*

The command operates on a task number (index) which must be within
* the valid range of existing tasks (0 to size-1) and can set the task
* as either completed or not completed.
* The index of the task to be marked (0-based)
* Flag indicating whether to mark the task as done (true) or not done (false)
* Constructs a new MarkCommand for the specified task number and completion status.
* @param taskNum    The index of the task to be marked (0-based index)
* @param isMarkedAsDone True to mark the task as done, false to mark as not done
* Executes the mark command by updating the completion status of the specified task
* and saving the changes to storage. The method validates that the task number is
* within the valid range before performing the operation.

*

After successfully marking the task, the updated task list is persisted to storage
* and a confirmation message is displayed to the user indicating the new status.
* @param tasks   The list of tasks containing the task to be marked
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism used to save the updated task list
* @return String containing the command's output message
* @throws InvalidFormatException if the task number is out of range (less than 0 or
*                                greater than or equal to the size of the task list)
* @throws IOException            if there is an error saving the task list to storage
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) throws InvalidFormatException, IOException {
throw new InvalidFormatException("Task number must be between 1 and " + tasks.size());
message = String.format(" Nice! I've marked this task as done:\n  %s", task);
message = String.format(" Okay, I've marked this task as not done:\n  %s", task);
* Handles the creation of todo tasks in the task management system.
* This command implementation processes user input to create new todo
* tasks and adds them to the task list.

*

The command requires a non-empty description for the todo task.
* The input string must be longer than 4 characters (excluding the
* "todo" command word) to be considered valid.
* TodoCommand cmd = new TodoCommand("todo read book");
* The minimum string length for "Todo" filter
* The raw input string containing the todo task description
* Constructs a new TodoCommand with the specified input string.
* @param input The raw input string containing the todo task description
* Executes the todo command by creating a new todo task and adding it
* to the task list. The method validates that the description is not empty

*

After successfully creating the task, it is added to the task list,
* the list is persisted to storage, and a confirmation message is displayed
* @param tasks   The list of tasks to which the new todo task will be added
* @param storage The data persistence mechanism used to save the updated task list
* @return String containing the command's output message
* @throws EmptyDescriptionException if the input description is empty or too short
* @throws IOException               if there is an error saving the task list to storage
public String execute(List<Task> tasks, DataPersistence storage) throws EmptyDescriptionException, IOException {
return String.format(" Got it. I've added this task:\n %s\n Now you have %d tasks in the list.",
* Defines the contract for persisting and retrieving task data in the task management system.
* This interface provides methods for saving tasks to and loading tasks from a persistent

*

Implementations of this interface should handle all the necessary data serialization,
* deserialization, and storage operations. They should also manage any required resources
* (like file handles or database connections) appropriately.
* Saves a list of tasks to persistent storage.

*

This method should handle the serialization of task objects and write them
* to the underlying storage medium. The entire operation should be atomic -
* either all tasks are saved successfully, or none are saved and an exception
* @param tasks The list of tasks to be saved
* @throws IOException if there is an error writing to the storage medium,
*                     such as file system errors or network issues
* Loads all tasks from persistent storage.

*

This method should handle reading and deserializing task objects from
* the underlying storage medium. If the storage is empty or has not been
* initialized, an empty list should be returned.
* @return A list containing all stored tasks, or an empty list if no tasks
* @throws IOException if there is an error reading from the storage medium,
*                     such as file system errors or network issues
* The TrashBot class represents the core of the TrashBot application.
* It processes user commands, manages tasks, and handles file storage.
* The TrashBot interacts with several command classes to manipulate and manage a list of tasks,
* and it also handles loading and saving tasks from/to a file.
* Constructs a new TrashBot instance and initializes it with a storage file.
* It loads the tasks from the specified storage file.
* @param storageFilePath the path to the file where tasks are stored
* @throws IOException if there is an issue reading the storage file
return response.isEmpty() ? "I've processed your command." : response;
* The input is parsed to determine the appropriate command, which is then executed.
* If the command is invalid or there is an error, an exception is caught and an error message is printed.
* @param input the command string from the user
* Parses the user's input command string and returns the corresponding command object.
* The input string is split into command type and arguments, which are then mapped to
* the corresponding command classes (e.g., TodoCommand, DeadlineCommand, etc.).
* @param input the command string to parse
* @return a Command object corresponding to the input command
* @throws UnknownInputException if the command type is not recognized
private Command parseCommand(String input) throws UnknownInputException {

* Constructs a new {@code UnknownInputException} with the specified detail message.
* @param input the detail message, which can be retrieved later by the {@link #getMessage()} method.
+ " Available input: todo, deadline, delete, event, mark, unmark, list, find, bye");

* Returns the string representation of the deadline task.

* Represents a time-bound event in the task management system.
* This class extends {@link Task} to include start and end times for events
* that occur during a specific time frame.

*

The class parses input strings in the format "event <description> /from <start> /to <end>"
* to create event tasks. Both start and end times are stored as strings to support
*   "event eat churros at clarke quay before drinking at red bridge
*   clarke quay before drinking at red bridge
* Constructs a new Event by parsing the input string to extract description
* @param input the raw input string in the format "event <description> /from <start> /to <end>"
String timeInfo = input.substring(input.indexOf("/from")); // get time - overall

* @return The event's start time as a string

* Base class representing a task with description and completion status.
* Creates a new task with the given description.
* Checks if the task is completed.

* Gets the status icon for display purposes.
return (isCompleted ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
* Represents a basic todo task in the task management system.
* This class extends {@link Task} to implement the simplest form of task
* that contains only a description without any additional time constraints.

*

Todo tasks are created from input strings in the format "todo <description>".
* The class strips the "todo " prefix from the input to extract the task description.
* Todo task = new Todo("todo Read chapter 5");
* Constructs a new Todo task by parsing the input string to extract the description.
* @param input The raw input string in the format "todo <description>"
* Represents a dialog box consisting of an image and a text label.
* This class is used for displaying user and bot (Duke) messages in the UI.
* Constructs a DialogBox with the specified text and image.
* Loads the FXML layout for the dialog box.
* @param text The text to be displayed in the dialog.
* @param img The image to be displayed alongside the dialog.
* Flips the dialog box such that the ImageView appears on the left and the text on the right.
* Creates a dialog box for user messages.
* @param text The text to be displayed.
* @param img The image representing the user.
* @return A DialogBox instance representing the user's message.
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
* Creates a dialog box for bot (Duke) messages, which are flipped to differentiate from user messages.
* @param text The text to be displayed.
* @param img The image representing the bot.
* @return A DialogBox instance representing the bot's message.
public static DialogBox getDukeDialog(String text, Image img) {
* The Launcher class serves as the entry point for the application.
* It starts the JavaFX application by invoking the launch method.
* The main method that launches the JavaFX application.
* @param args Command-line arguments passed to the application.
* The Main class serves as the entry point for the TrashBot application.
* It initializes the TrashBot instance, loads the user interface, and sets up the primary stage.
* Starts the JavaFX application by initializing TrashBot, loading the FXML layout,
* @param stage The primary stage for the application.
* The main method that launches the JavaFX application.
* @param args Command-line arguments passed to the application.
* The MainWindow class controls the user interface of the TrashBot application.
* It handles user input, displays output, and interacts with the TrashBot logic.
* Initializes the MainWindow by setting up an output stream to capture TrashBot output.
* Sets the TrashBot instance and displays a welcome message.
* @param tb The TrashBot instance to be used.
addBotMessage("Hello! I'm TrashBot\nWhat can I do for you?");
* Handles user input when the send button is clicked or Enter is pressed.
* Captures and processes the command, then displays the response.
* Provides the user interface for the TrashBot task management system.
* This class handles user input/output and manages the interaction between
* the user and the core TrashBot functionality.

*

The UI implements a simple command-line interface that:

*
  • Passes commands to the TrashBot core for processing

*
  • Handles any errors that occur during operation
* Constructs a new UI instance for the specified TrashBot.
* @param trashBot The TrashBot instance to be controlled through this UI
* Starts the UI and begins processing user input.
* This method runs continuously until the program is terminated,
* reading commands from standard input and passing them to TrashBot

*

The method handles empty input by ignoring it and continues
* to the next command. Any exceptions that occur during processing
* are caught and result in program termination with an error message.
drawBorder(" Hello! I'm TrashBot\n What can I do you for?");
* Draws a decorative border around the specified content.
* Used to improve the visual presentation of messages in the UI.
* @param content The text to be surrounded with borders
String input = "T | 1 | eat mee hoon kway";

Deadline deadline = new Deadline("deadline submit report /by 2023-09-11 0133");
